articles.headline: Back to Being Just a Senator, Clinton Inspects Crop Damage
articles.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton visited storm-damaged orchards in upstate New York as she transitioned back from being a presidential candidate.
articles.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton visited storm-damaged orchards in upstate New York as she transitioned back from being a presidential candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, N.Y.  The big black Ford Explorer rumbled down the gravel road on Wednesday and came to a stop. Out climbed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who started walking toward an orchard, alongside local farmers.

articles.headline: Fund Manager Who Faked His Suicide Surrenders
articles.snippet: Samuel Israel III, a fugitive hedge fund swindler who faked his suicide on the day he was to report to prison, turned himself in after speaking to his mother by phone.
articles.abstract: Samuel Israel III, a fugitive hedge fund swindler who faked his suicide on the day he was to report to prison, turned himself in after speaking to his mother by phone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samuel Israel III tricked his investors, lied to his lawyers and misled the police. But in the end, he listened to his mother.
articles.byline: By Abha Bhattarai and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: McCain Orders Shake-Up of His Campaign
articles.snippet: John McCain placed a veteran of President Bush’s 2004 re-election in charge of day-to-day operations.
articles.abstract: John McCain placed a veteran of President Bush’s 2004 re-election in charge of day-to-day operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign has gone through its second shake-up in a year. Responding to Republican concerns that his candidacy was faltering, Mr. McCain put a veteran of President Bush’s 2004 campaign in charge of day-to-day operations, and stepped away from a plan to have the campaign run by 11 regional managers, Mr. McCain’s aides said Wednesday.

articles.headline: Big Job Cuts Announced at American
articles.snippet: American Airlines said it expects to cut nearly 7,000 jobs, about 8 percent of its work force, by the end of 2008, as it reduces flights and grounds aircraft due to high fuel prices.
articles.abstract: American Airlines said it expects to cut nearly 7,000 jobs, about 8 percent of its work force, by the end of 2008, as it reduces flights and grounds aircraft due to high fuel prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Airlines expects to cut nearly 7,000 employees by the end of the year, or about 8 percent of its worldwide work force, as it reduces flights and grounds aircraft because of high fuel costs, the airline told employees Wednesday.

articles.headline: The Struggles of Detroit Ensnare Its Workers
articles.snippet: Detroit automakers will temporarily lay off upward of 25,000 workers this year, but are still obligated to pay them more than half of their take-home wages.
articles.abstract: Detroit automakers will temporarily lay off upward of 25,000 workers this year, but are still obligated to pay them more than half of their take-home wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Their pickups and sport utility vehicles are not selling, and now General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler have to pay thousands of auto workers not to make them.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Panel Questions State Dept. Role in Iraq Oil Deal
articles.snippet: Bush administration officials knew that an oil company with close ties to President Bush planned to sign an oil deal with the Kurdistan government, counter to U.S. policy.
articles.abstract: Bush administration officials knew that an oil company with close ties to President Bush planned to sign an oil deal with the Kurdistan government, counter to U.S. policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bush administration officials knew that a Texas oil company with close ties to President Bush was planning to sign an oil deal with the regional Kurdistan government that ran counter to American policy and undercut Iraq’s central government, a Congressional committee has concluded.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: Colombia Plucks Hostages From Rebels’ Grasp
articles.snippet: Commandos spirited 15 hostages to freedom, including the politician Ingrid Betancourt and three Americans.
articles.abstract: Commandos spirited 15 hostages to freedom, including the politician Ingrid Betancourt and three Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombian commandos in disguise spirited 15 hostages to freedom on Wednesday, including Ingrid Betancourt, a French-Colombian politician held for six years, and three American military contractors.

articles.headline: A Lucrative Deal for Rush Limbaugh
articles.snippet: In an interview with The New York Times Magazine, the talk show radio host said he would receive a $100 million signing bonus and about $38 million a year for eight years under the new contract.
articles.abstract: In an interview with The New York Times Magazine, the talk show radio host said he would receive a $100 million signing bonus and about $38 million a year for eight years under the new contract.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talk was never cheap for Rush Limbaugh, but now it is getting a lot more expensive.

articles.headline: Digital Pens to Write on Any Paper
articles.snippet: Two new digital pens don’t need special paper to write on. But there are a few glitches.
articles.abstract: Two new digital pens don’t need special paper to write on. But there are a few glitches.
articles.lead_paragraph: In gadget-head circles, one of this summer’s most buzzworthy new products is the Pulse pen: a ballpoint that simultaneously records both your handwriting and the sound of the words you are transcribing. Both are transferred to a Windows PC when you return home  seemingly perfect for lecture-hall students, journalists and note-takers of any kind.

articles.headline: Price of Oil Rises Again, Rattling the Markets
articles.snippet: Crude oil closed at $143.57 a barrel, another record, sending shudders through financial markets already worried about the prospect of a global economic slowdown.
articles.abstract: Crude oil closed at $143.57 a barrel, another record, sending shudders through financial markets already worried about the prospect of a global economic slowdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A sharp increase in oil prices on Wednesday sent shudders through anxious financial markets already worried about the prospect of a global economic slowdown.
